TextEquiv.Unicode: that too in the verie same body where
in now we live.
I will adde a fewe testimonies to
proove the resurrection of our flesh.
Job confessing his faith touthing the
resurrection of the dead in his great
weakenesse, affliction and fickenesse,
saith: I knowe that iny redeemer li
veth, and that in the last daie l shall
rise out of the earth, and shall be clad
againe with my skinne, and in my flesh
I shall see God: whom even I my selfe
shall sce, and my cies shall behold and
vone other. This hope is layde up in
my bosome. This testimonie is so e
vident as that it needeth no larger an
exposition.
No lesse evident are those testimo
nies out of Claie, chap26. Ezek. 37.
Psalme 15. Math. 22. John 56.11.
Throughout the Actes in everie place
is often repeated the resurrection of ye
dead. saint Paul in the 15. cha. of his
first Epistle to the Corinthians, doeth
make a full discourse of this resurrec
tion. In the fourth chapter of his 2. E
pistle he saith: we which live are al
waies delivered to death, for Jesus
sake, that the life of Jesus also might
appeare in our mortall flesh. See now
what coulde be spoken more plainely,
than that the life of Christ shall bee
made to appeare in this mortall flesh
of ours: For by and by after he sayth:
We knowe that he hath raised up the
Lorde Jesus, shall raise us up also by
the meanes of Jesus. And in the fifth
chapter againe: wee must all ap
peare before the judgement seate of
Christ (saith he) that everie man may
receive the workes of his bodie, ac
cording to that hee hath done, whe
ther it bee good or evill. Therefore
these verie bodies of ours shall rise a
gaine in the day of judgement.
And nowe (dearely beloved) I have to

that too in the verie same body where in now we live. I will adde a fewe testimonies to proove the resurrection of our flesh. Job confessing his faith touthing the resurrection of the dead in his great weakenesse, affliction and fickenesse, saith: I knowe that iny redeemer li veth, and that in the last daie l shall rise out of the earth, and shall be clad againe with my skinne, and in my flesh I shall see God: whom even I my selfe shall sce, and my cies shall behold and vone other. This hope is layde up in my bosome. This testimonie is so e vident as that it needeth no larger an exposition. No lesse evident are those testimo nies out of Claie, chap26. Ezek. 37. Psalme 15. Math. 22. John 56.11. Throughout the Actes in everie place is often repeated the resurrection of ye dead. saint Paul in the 15. cha. of his first Epistle to the Corinthians, doeth make a full discourse of this resurrec tion. In the fourth chapter of his 2. E pistle he saith: we which live are al waies delivered to death, for Jesus sake, that the life of Jesus also might appeare in our mortall flesh. See now what coulde be spoken more plainely, than that the life of Christ shall bee made to appeare in this mortall flesh of ours: For by and by after he sayth: We knowe that he hath raised up the Lorde Jesus, shall raise us up also by the meanes of Jesus. And in the fifth chapter againe: wee must all ap peare before the judgement seate of Christ (saith he) that everie man may receive the workes of his bodie, ac cording to that hee hath done, whe ther it bee good or evill. Therefore these verie bodies of ours shall rise a gaine in the day of judgement. And nowe (dearely beloved) I have to
declare unto you in what manner our
bodies shall rise againe, and of what
forte they shall be in the resurrection
In the shuttiug uppe and ende of all
ages or of this world, our Lord Jesus
Christ shall come to iudgement with
great maiestie, and then whomsoever
that daie shall finde alive, they shal in
a moment of time be chaunged, and
first I saye ) shall all they that died
from the first Adam to the last that
shall die, rise uppe againe, and in their
owne flesh stande among the living
that are chaunged before the Tribu
nall seate of Christ, looking for that
last pronounced sentence in judge
ment.
This doth Paul set downe in these
wordes, Loe, I tell you a mysterie, we
shall not all verily sleepe, but we shall
all be chaunged in a moment of time
in the twinckling of an eye, at the
founde of the last trumpe: For it shall
founde, and the dead shall rise againe
incorruptibly, and we shall be chaun
ged. For this corruptible must put on
incorruption, and this mortall must
put on immortalitle.
By this evident testimonie of the
Apostle, we may gather in what fa
shion our bodies shall be in that resur
rection: Verily our bodies shall bee
none other in the resurrection than
now they be, this onely excepted, that
they shal be cleane without all corrup
tion, and corruptible affection. For
the Apostle saith, The dead shall rise
againe: And we shalbe chaunged.
And againe pointing expresly and
precisely to these verie bodies which
here wee beare about, he saith: This
corruptible, This mortall, yea, This
bodie I saie, and no other, as Job al
so witnessed, shall rise againe: and that
shall rise againe incorruptible, which
was corruptible : that shal kise againe

declare unto you in what manner our bodies shall rise againe, and of what forte they shall be in the resurrection In the shuttiug uppe and ende of all ages or of this world, our Lord Jesus Christ shall come to iudgement with great maiestie, and then whomsoever that daie shall finde alive, they shal in a moment of time be chaunged, and first I saye ) shall all they that died from the first Adam to the last that shall die, rise uppe againe, and in their owne flesh stande among the living that are chaunged before the Tribu nall seate of Christ, looking for that last pronounced sentence in judge ment. This doth Paul set downe in these wordes, Loe, I tell you a mysterie, we shall not all verily sleepe, but we shall all be chaunged in a moment of time in the twinckling of an eye, at the founde of the last trumpe: For it shall founde, and the dead shall rise againe incorruptibly, and we shall be chaun ged. For this corruptible must put on incorruption, and this mortall must put on immortalitle. By this evident testimonie of the Apostle, we may gather in what fa shion our bodies shall be in that resur rection: Verily our bodies shall bee none other in the resurrection than now they be, this onely excepted, that they shal be cleane without all corrup tion, and corruptible affection. For the Apostle saith, The dead shall rise againe: And we shalbe chaunged. And againe pointing expresly and precisely to these verie bodies which here wee beare about, he saith: This corruptible, This mortall, yea, This bodie I saie, and no other, as Job al so witnessed, shall rise againe: and that shall rise againe incorruptible, which was corruptible : that shal kise againe
